content: The "Minority Inclusion in Clinical Trials Act of 2015" emphasizes the need to increase representation of underrepresented communities in clinical trials, as stated by the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities. The National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities is urged by Congress to include ways to increase underrepresented communities in clinical trials. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants for expanding opportunities for scientists and researchers and promoting the inclusion of underrepresented minorities in the health professions. Support for institutions in underrepresented communities for workforce development. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible entities that focus on health workforce development in underrepresented communities, including historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving health professions schools, Hispanic-serving institutions, and tribal colleges and universities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible entities focusing on health workforce development in underrepresented communities, including historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving health professions schools, tribal colleges and universities, and institutions with programs to recruit and retain underrepresented minority health professionals. Entities eligible for grants must include underrepresented minority health professional associations and institutions located in communities with predominantly underrepresented minority populations. These institutions must have partnerships to increase workforce diversity and enroll at least 20 percent underrepresented minorities. Funds received must be used to expand existing diversity programs. The grant funds must be used to expand, implement, or evaluate workforce diversity programs, including mental health care professions. Programs should enhance diversity by considering minority status in qualifications. Activities may include educational outreach, scholarship programs, postbaccalaureate programs, and academic enrichment programs targeting non-competitive individuals for health professions schools. The curr_chunk discusses various programs funded by grants, such as loan cancellation, postbaccalaureate, academic enrichment, mentoring, internship, community partnership, and leadership training programs. Grantees are required to submit reports summarizing and evaluating their activities. The term "Asian-American, Native" is defined in this section. Grantees must submit annual reports summarizing and evaluating activities funded by grants. The term "Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" is defined in this section. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2015 through 2020. SEC. 5. ELIMINATING DISPARITIES IN MATERNITY HEALTH OUTCOMES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with various healthcare organizations, will conduct research to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with healthcare organizations, will conduct research and implement interventions to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes, including expanding access to quality maternity care for vulnerable populations and establishing a demonstration project to assess effective interventions. The Secretary will conduct a demonstration project in up to 8 States to test various models of interventions aimed at reducing disparities in maternal health outcomes. States will be selected based on applications specifying regions and populations to be served, ensuring representation of affected communities. The Secretary will conduct a demonstration project in up to 8 States to test interventions for reducing maternal health outcome disparities. Criteria will ensure diverse models are tested with existing evidence base. Projects will involve local provider organizations and run from January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2019. Grants may be provided for evaluation and monitoring. The demonstration project under subsection (a)(3) will run from January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2019. The Secretary may provide grants for evaluation and monitoring purposes. States participating in the project must report data on outcomes, costs, and quality of maternity care to the Secretary. The Secretary will monitor project outcomes, costs, and quality of maternity care. They will also evaluate the rationale for bundled payment selection. A final report on the project results is due by December 31, 2020. SEC. 6. HEALTH DISPARITIES EDUCATION PROGRAM. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program in collaboration with various entities to inform professionals and the public about reducing racial and ethnic disparities. This program will include public awareness and outreach campaigns targeting the general public and the medical community. The Secretary will disseminate scientific evidence on racial and ethnic disparities in health care, including factors like age, disability status, and socioeconomic status, to reduce disparities. The Secretary will disseminate scientific evidence on racial and ethnic disparities in health care, including factors like age, disability status, socioeconomic status, sex, gender identity, and sexual orientation, to reduce disparities and improve access to language services for those with limited-English proficiency. The Secretary will disseminate information on racial, ethnic, disability, socioeconomic, sex, gender identity, and sexual orientation data collection. Specific educational initiatives will be designed for healthcare providers to address disparities. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2015 through 2020.
